headline: Here’s How to Make Moonstruck Eggs, the Very First Egg-in-a-Hole
description: A recipe for Italian-style egg-in-a-hole, inspired by the movie "Moonstruck".
recipeIngredient: 2 slices hearty sandwich bread (about 3/4-inch thick), such as peasant bread, sourdough, whole-wheat, or multi-grain
1  large roasted red pepper (from a 12-ounce jar), patted dry and sliced
Chopped fresh chives or parsley, for garnish (optional)

recipeInstructions.name: Step 1
recipeInstructions.text: Cut a hole in the middle of each bread slice using a 2-inch round cutter or the rim of a small glass.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 2
recipeInstructions.text: Melt the butter in a large cast iron or nonstick skillet over medium heat. Swirl the pan as the butter melts to evenly coat the surface. The pan is ready when the butter begins sizzling. Add the red pepper, garlic, a pinch of salt, and several grinds of black pepper. Cook until fragrant and warmed through, 1 to 2 minutes.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 3
recipeInstructions.text: Push the pepper mixture to one side. Place the bread slices on the other side and cook until toasted and golden-brown, 3 to 5 minutes.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 4
recipeInstructions.text: Flip the bread slices. Crack an egg into each hole and season with a pinch of salt and several grinds of black pepper. Cover and cook until the eggs are just set and other side of the bread is golden-brown, 2 to 3 minutes more.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 5
recipeInstructions.text: Transfer the pepper mixture onto each egg-in-a-hole. Transfer to plates, garnish with the chives or parsley, if using, and serve.

name: Here’s How to Make Moonstruck Eggs, the Very First Egg-in-a-Hole

author.name: Sheela Prakash
author.description: Sheela is the Senior Contributing Food Editor at Kitchn and the author of Mediterranean Every Day: Simple, Inspired Recipes for Feel-Good Food. She received her master's degree from the University of Gastronomic Sciences in Italy and is also a Registered Dietitian.
